subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] International Quikscript
msgSnippet: ... In order to do so well, it would have to have much of the flexibility of the IPA, at least for the vowels.  The Southern Hemisphere accents, the U.S.
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman scripsit:

> Previously I felt that one of the strengths of QS was that it had the
> expressive power to represent regional accents.

In order to do so well, it would have to have much of the flexibility
of the IPA, at least for the vowels. The Southern Hemisphere accents,
the U.S. Northern Cities accent, and some of the accents of England
in particular are very different from their relatives.

> The proposal below is excellent.

Thank you.

> The task of putting together the clues in the Quickscript Manual,
> though, requires the perspective of a deeper understanding of different
> accents of English than most people have. What is needed is a new
> manual, with some discussion of the Wells lexical sets and numerous
> examples of the use of an international QS.

Indeed. Several parts of the proposed scheme can only be explained with
respect to Orthodox spelling.

> I don't know if you have the time or interest in doing this, John,

At the moment I don't, which is a pity because I'd like to do it.
But don't let that stop anyone.

> PS. Aside: In my own writing I've abandoned the QS abbreviations in
> favor of a system in which all vowels are spelled.

I think that's the right thing. Shorthand has its place, but so does
longhand.

> So how do I answer Read's question as to the spelling of "the"? I
> spell it with #8 They + #27 Eat, which I find I read back in either
> the emphasized or unemphasized pronunciation with no hesitation.

Indeed. There are many short English words that have both strong and
weak pronunciations. For example, the words "him" and "her" have weak
pronunciations without the "h" (this has nothing to do with h-dropping in
certain accents; it is a universal feature of up-to-speed English speech).
In the same way, the strong form of "you" has Ooze, whereas the weak form
has Utter. No proposed orthography that I know of represents the weak
form of any word other than "the", and why should it be an exception to
the strong-only rule?

--
John Cowan <cowan@...> http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
Charles li reis, nostre emperesdre magnes,
Set anz totz pleinz ad ested in Espagnes.
